instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP3V_S4: What is PP3V_S4? This is a typo of PP3V3_S4 When you see PP3V_S4, assume they meant to type PP3V3_S4.
definitions.PP5_S0: What is PP5_S0? This is a typo of PP5V_S0 When you see PP5_S0, assume they meant to type PP5V_S0.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead board
threads.message:
board came in dead, I’ve Amber light on charger, I’ve complete voltage of the power aliases, no fan spin, 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V_S4</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S2</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL>
All this rails are all present on the board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead board
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead board
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead board
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead board
threads.message: Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and there was fan spin, board came alive, also checked the resistance of the voltage dividers in the circuit they were all intact, at <CHIP>U8150</CHIP>/5 is grounded, <CHIP>U8150</CHIP>/7 is 1.07V and <CHIP>U8150</CHIP>/1 is 0.9V. That pin5 shouldn’t be grounded I check the voltage divider resistance in that circuit they seem intact.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead board
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> is a redundant protection.
You can let the board as is, if works.
But shouldn't be too difficult to fix pin 5 issue.

What is <RESISTOR>R8151</RESISTOR>/52 common point voltage?
If good (1V aprox), change <RESISTOR>R8153</RESISTOR> and/or <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>.
I no ggod, check <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> presence at <RESISTOR>R8151</RESISTOR> pin 1.
